pandas & tidyverse: The basics

Python & R

Comparing how to do the most basic of tasks in pandas and the tidyverse: creating, reading, and writing tabular data.

Author

Ivan Dubrovin

Published

June 15, 2022

Iâ€™m starting a series of posts that compare how to do the same things in Python and R. This is the first one, comparing the most basic things: creating, printing, reading, and writing tabular data in pandas and the tidyverse. There will be nothing complex here, I am mostly trying out the format.

The code examples are based on the Pandas course on Kaggle.

Attaching libraries

The easiest. Here is Python:

import pandas as pd

And here::here() is R:

library(tidyverse)

Creating data

Not always is data available in a nicely formatted UTF-8 encoded CSVs that we can read in. Sometimes, there is a need to create a table by hand. Letâ€™s take a look at how to create small toy tables (to use as test cases, for example).

In Python, the easiest way to do that is to pass a dictionary where keys are column names and values are lists of values to the pd.DataFrame initializer:

toy_table = pd.DataFrame({
    "Apples": [35, 41],
    "Bananas": [21, 34],
})
toy_table
   Apples  Bananas
0      35       21
1      41       34

In R, tribble function exists specifically to simplify this task of creating a small example tables:

tribble(
    ~Apples, ~Bananas,
    30,      21,
    41,      34
)
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  Apples Bananas
   <dbl>   <dbl>
1     30      21
2     41      34

Reading the data

The function to read data from a file is called read_csv for both. In both, it is insanely customizable by a huge amount of arguments. For example, pandas separates the index into itâ€™s own entity that is r/notlikeothercolumns, and if the index is explicitly written in the file, we can make it interpret it as such by passing an integer column position or a string column name to the index_col argument:

dd = pd.read_csv("games-first15.csv", index_col=0)
dd.head()
          rated  ...  opening_ply
id               ...             
TZJHLljE  False  ...            5
l1NXvwaE   True  ...            4
mIICvQHh   True  ...            3
kWKvrqYL   True  ...            3
9tXo1AUZ   True  ...            5

[5 rows x 15 columns]

tidyverse does not care for indexes and will read everything as ordinary columns. It is, however, very talkative and reports the detected column types by default. We can ask it to be quiet by disabling the show_col_types flag:

dd <- read_csv("games-first15.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)
head(dd)
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 16
  id    rated created_at last_move_at turns victory_status winner increment_code
  <chr> <lgl>      <dbl>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <chr>  <chr>         
1 TZJHâ€¦ FALSE    1.50e12      1.50e12    13 outoftime      white  15+2          
2 l1NXâ€¦ TRUE     1.50e12      1.50e12    16 resign         black  5+10          
3 mIICâ€¦ TRUE     1.50e12      1.50e12    61 mate           white  5+10          
4 kWKvâ€¦ TRUE     1.50e12      1.50e12    61 mate           white  20+0          
5 9tXoâ€¦ TRUE     1.50e12      1.50e12    95 mate           white  30+3          
6 MsoDâ€¦ FALSE    1.50e12      1.50e12     5 draw           draw   10+0          
# â€¦ with 8 more variables: white_id <chr>, white_rating <dbl>, black_id <chr>,
#   black_rating <dbl>, moves <chr>, opening_eco <chr>, opening_name <chr>,
#   opening_ply <dbl>

Writing the data

Writing the data to files is even easier than reading them in. Again, both are highly configurable. In pandas a DataFrame has a method called to_csv. Here it is in use, asked nicely to not include the index into the output:

dd.to_csv("out.csv", index=False)

In tidyverse, the write_csv function takes in the table to write and a path to write it to:

write_csv(dd, "out.csv")
